</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In July 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;146,
&#147;Accounting for Cost Associated with Exit or Disposal
Activities.&#148; SFAS No.&nbsp;146 addresses financial
accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or
disposal activities and nullifies Emerging Issues Task Force
(&#147;EITF&#148;) Issue No.&nbsp;94-3, &#147;Liability
Recognition for Certain Employee Termination Benefits and Other
Costs to Exit an Activity (Including Certain Costs Incurred in a
Restructuring).&#148; SFAS No.&nbsp;146 requires that a
liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal
activity be recognized when the liability is incurred. The
provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 are effective for exit or
disposal activities that are initiated after December&nbsp;31,
2002. The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 did not have a material
impact on the Company&#146;s fiscal 2002 financial statements
and is not expected to have a material ongoing impact.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Reclassifications</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Certain reclassifications have been made to the
February&nbsp;2, 2002 and February&nbsp;3, 2001 financial
statements to conform with the February&nbsp;1, 2003
presentation.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity
Transactions</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During the years ended February&nbsp;1, 2003,
February&nbsp;2, 2002 and February&nbsp;3, 2001, the Company
declared and paid dividends totaling $0.35 per share, $0.31 per
share and $0.27 per share, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;10, 2000, the Company&#146;s
Board of Directors authorized a two-for-one stock split of its
common stock. The stock split was effected by issuing one
additional share of common stock for each outstanding share of
common stock and each treasury share of common stock. The stock
split was effective as
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-13
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE TALBOTS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">Dollar amounts in thousands except share
data</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">of the close of business on November&nbsp;7, 2000
to shareholders of record on October&nbsp;25, 2000. All share
information contained in this report reflects the impact of the
stock split.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 1995, the Company adopted a stock repurchase
plan authorizing the purchase of shares of its common stock.
Subsequently, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors approved
extensions to the original plan. During 2001, the Company
repurchased 3,209,008 shares under its repurchase program at an
average price of $31.16. During 2002, the Company repurchased
3,165,697 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock under its
repurchase programs at an average price per share of $31.59.
This completed a $50.0&nbsp;million repurchase program approved
by the Board of Directors in October 2001 and a subsequent $50.0
million plan that was approved by the Board of Directors in July
2002. In October 2002, the Board of Directors approved a further
stock repurchase program which allows the Company to purchase an
additional $50.0&nbsp;million in stock from time to time over
the next two years. Through February&nbsp;1, 2003, no purchases
have been made under this plan. At February&nbsp;1, 2003 and
February&nbsp;2, 2002, the Company held 17,764,211 and
14,553,450 shares, respectively, as treasury shares. Treasury
shares also include shares forfeited under the Company&#146;s
restricted stock grants under the 1993 Executive Stock Based
Incentive Plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;).
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock
Options</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 1993, the Company reserved 5,300,000 shares of
common stock for issuance pursuant to the Plan. In 1998 and
2002, the Plan was amended and approved by stockholders to
increase the number of shares of common stock authorized
thereunder by 6,620,000 and 300,000 shares, respectively, to
12,220,000 shares. In accordance with the Plan, the Company
issued stock options that vest over a three-year period and
expire no later than ten years from the grant date. These stock
options have been granted at fair market value at the date of
grant.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 1995, the Company implemented a stock option
plan for its non-employee members of its Board of Directors. In
2000, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors and shareholders
approved a Restated Directors Plan (the &#147;Restated Directors
Plan&#148;) which increased the shares reserved for issuance by
800,000 shares. Stock options granted under the Restated
Directors Plan generally vest over a three-year period and
expire no later than ten years from the grant date. The stock
options are granted at a price equal to the fair market value of
the Company&#146;s common stock at the date of grant.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following table summarizes information
regarding stock options outstanding under the Plan and the
Restated Directors Plan at February&nbsp;1, 2003.

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE TALBOTS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the provisions of the Plan, the Company has
issued to certain key members of management shares of restricted
stock. The purchase price of the restricted stock is $0.01 per
share. The difference between the market price of the shares on
the date of grant and management&#146;s cost of $0.01 per share
is recorded as deferred compensation and is amortized over a
five-year service period. Such shares are contingently
returnable, at the $0.01 par value, if the employee does not
fulfill their service obligation.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">A summary of the changes in restricted shares
outstanding for the years ended February&nbsp;1, 2003,
February&nbsp;2, 2002, and February&nbsp;3, 2001 is presented
below.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company uses the intrinsic value method to
measure compensation expense associated with grants of stock
options to employees.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party
and Affiliates</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In November 1993, the Company purchased certain
trademarks, including the Talbots trade name, from JUSCO
(Europe) B.V., a related party. In 2001, JUSCO (Europe) B.V.,
which retained rights to certain trademarks in specified Asian
territories, was dissolved and these Asian trademark rights were
transferred to AEON Co., Ltd.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">AEON Co. Ltd., owns and operates stores in Japan
through its wholly owned subsidiary Talbots Japan Co., Ltd.
(&#147;Talbots Japan&#148;). The Company provides certain
services for Talbots Japan and is reimbursed for expenses
incurred. At February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002,
the Company was owed $8,759 and $9,605 respectively, for these
service costs and for merchandise inventory purchases made on
behalf of Talbots Japan.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-15
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE TALBOTS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">Dollar amounts in thousands except share
data</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Talbots has an advisory services agreement with
AEON U.S.A. under which AEON U.S.A. provides advice and services
to Talbots with respect to strategic planning and other related
issues concerning the Company and maintains on behalf of the
Company a working relationship with banks and other financial
institution, in particular, Japanese banks, for which AEON
U.S.A. receives an annual fee of $250 plus any expenses incurred.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the Company&#146;s established stock
repurchase programs, shares are repurchased from the open market
from time to time. Concurrently with such open market purchases,
the Company has generally purchased a pro rata number of shares
from Aeon USA so as to maintain substantially the same
percentage stock ownership of the Company between Aeon USA and
the public shareholders. During fiscal 2002, a total of
1,054,936 shares were repurchased from Aeon USA. The price of
the shares purchased from Aeon USA was equal to the weighted
average price of the shares paid to the public shareholders and
for fiscal 2002 ranged from $25.03 to $30.15.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Debt</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revolving
Credit</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The revolving credit agreements with four banks
have maximum available borrowings of $100,000, have two-year
terms and can be extended annually upon mutual agreement.
Interest terms on the unsecured revolving credit agreements are
fixed, at the Company&#146;s option, for periods of one, three
or six months. At February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2,
2002, the Company had $100,000 outstanding under its revolving
credit agreements. None of the outstanding balance is currently
payable.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-17
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Notes Payable
to Banks</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company also has available a $125,000
unsecured line-of-credit facility with five banks. At
February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002, no amounts were
outstanding on this facility. The weighted average interest rate
for the years ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2,
2002 was 2.32% and 3.33%, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letters of
Credit</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has two letter-of-credit banking
agreements totaling $200,000 which it uses primarily for the
purchase of merchandise inventories. At February&nbsp;1, 2003
and February&nbsp;2, 2002, the Company held $107,558 and
$101,455, respectively, in purchase commitments.
</FONT>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At February&nbsp;1, 2003, a consolidated foreign
subsidiary of the Company had net operating loss carryforwards
of $4,238 which are expected to be utilized in 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">For the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;1, 2003,
the effective tax rate decreased to 37.5% compared to 38.0% for
the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-19
</FONT>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment and
Geographic Information</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has segmented its operations in a
manner that reflects how its chief operating decision-maker
reviews the results of the operating segments that make up the
consolidated entity.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has two reportable segments, its
retail stores (the &#147;Stores Segment&#148;), which include
the Company&#146;s United States, Canada and United Kingdom
retail store operations, and its catalog operations (the
&#147;Catalog Segment&#148;), which includes both catalog and
internet operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s reportable segments offer
similar products; however, each segment requires different
marketing and management strategies. The Stores Segment derives
its revenues from the sale of women&#146;s and children&#146;s
classic apparel, accessories and shoes, through its retail
stores, while the Catalog Segment derives its revenues through
its approximately 25 distinct catalog mailings per year and
through its e-commerce site at www.talbots.com.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company evaluates the operating performance
of its identified segments based on a direct profit measure. The
accounting policies of the segments are generally the same as
those described in the summary of significant accounting
policies, except as follows: direct profit is calculated as net
sales less cost of goods sold and direct expenses, such as
payroll, occupancy and other direct costs. Indirect expenses are
not allocated on a segment basis; therefore, no measure of
segment net income or loss is available. Assets are not
allocated between segments; therefore, no measure of segment
assets is available.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Historically, the Company does not allocate
assets by segment, however, SFAS&nbsp;142 requires goodwill and
other intangible assets to be allocated to specific reporting
segments. For analysis of impairment under FASB&nbsp;142,
Talbots allocated goodwill for $35.5&nbsp;million and $0 to the
stores and catalog segment, respectively, at February&nbsp;1,
2003 February&nbsp;2, 2002. The trademark was allocated as
$64.5&nbsp;million and $11.4&nbsp;million to the stores and
catalog segment, respectively, at February&nbsp;1, 2003 and
February&nbsp;2, 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-20
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The classification &#147;Foreign&#148; is
comprised of the Company&#146;s Canada and United Kingdom retail
store operations and the classification &#147;United
States&#148; is comprised of the Company&#146;s United States
retail store operations and the Company&#146;s Catalog
operations.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-21
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE TALBOTS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">Dollar amounts in thousands except share
data</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">12.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Benefit Plans</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company sponsors a non-contributory defined
benefit pension plan covering substantially all domestic
salaried and hourly employees. The plan provides retirement
benefits for employees who have attained age&nbsp;21 and
completed one year of service. The benefit formula for salaried
and hourly corporate employees is a final average pay benefit
formula and the benefit formula for store employees is a career
pay formula. The Company&#146;s general funding policy is to
contribute the greater of amounts that are deductible for
federal income tax purposes or required by law. Plan assets for
the pension plan consist principally of fixed income and equity
securities.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following sets forth the funded status and
prepaid pension cost for the Company&#146;s pension plan:
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="90%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="54%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="8%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="8%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="8%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="8%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">February 1, 2003</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">February 2, 2002</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company also has a non-qualified supplemental
executive retirement plan (&#147;SERP&#148;) for certain key
executives impacted by Internal Revenue Code limits on benefits
and compensation. The plan is not funded.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has a qualified defined contribution
401(k) plan, which covers substantially all employees. Employees
make contributions to the plan, and the Company makes a cash
contribution that matches 50% of an employee&#146;s contribution
up to a maximum of 6% of the employee&#146;s actual
compensation. Employees may elect to invest in the common stock
of the Company at their discretion. Company contributions for
the years ended February&nbsp;1, 2003, February&nbsp;2, 2002 and
February&nbsp;3, 2001 were $3,318, $3,118 and $3,190,
respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company provides certain medical benefits for
most retired employees. The following sets forth the funded
status and accrued benefit cost for the postretirement medical
plan.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-24
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average discount rate used in
determining the accumulated postretirement medical benefit
obligation was 6.75% at February&nbsp;1, 2003 and 7.50% at
February&nbsp;2, 2002 and February&nbsp;3, 2001. Additionally,
assumed cost escalation rates that start at 9.00% and grade down
gradually to 5.00% were used for February&nbsp;1, 2003. Assumed
cost escalation rates that start at 10.00% and grade down
gradually to 5.00% were used for February&nbsp;2, 2002 and
assumed escalation rates that start at 8.10% and grade down
gradually to 5.00% were used for the year ended February&nbsp;3,
2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company provides postemployment medical
benefits to certain employees on short-term disability. The
Company&#146;s obligation at February&nbsp;1, 2003 and
February&nbsp;2, 2002 was $880 and $634, respectively
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE TALBOTS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>

<B><FONT size="2">Dollar amounts in thousands except share

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">13.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company conducts the major part of its
operations in leased premises with lease terms expiring at
various dates through 2025. Most store leases provide for base
rentals plus contingent rentals which are a function of sales
volume and provide that the Company pay real estate taxes,
maintenance and other operating expenses applicable to the
leased premises. Additionally, most store leases provide renewal
options and contain rent escalation clauses. These escalation
clauses are factored into a calculation of the future rental
stream. This stream is recorded on a straight-line basis over
the life of the original lease. The &#147;deferred rent under
lease commitments&#148; caption represents rent expensed in
excess of cash paid. Management expects that in the normal
course of business expiring leases will be renewed or replaced
by other leases.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The aggregate minimum future annual rental
commitments under noncancelable operating leases at
February&nbsp;1, 2003 are as follows:
</FONT>

at April&nbsp;1, 2003 was 546.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">The payment of dividends and the amount thereof
is determined by the Board of Directors and depends, among other
factors, upon the Company&#146;s earnings, operations, financial
condition, capital requirements and general business outlook at
the time payment is considered. The Company anticipates that
dividends on the common stock will continue to be declared on a
quarterly basis.
